LANGUAGES OF THE ASSEMBLY
(Appointment of Select Committee)


    Order read for resumption of proceedings - [8th February]:

    That this Assembly is of the opinion that for the purposes of oral debate the languages of the Assembly should be English, Malay, Mandarin and Tamil; and that a Select Committee be appointed to examine, report upon and make recommendations in respect of matters necessary to enable effect to be given to the proposal.

    The Chief Minister: If it please you, Sir, yesterday I dealt with one danger which I think we must face in this very crucial issue.

    This morning I would like to deal with just one other matter, an argument which has been consistently repeated in private, though rarely in public, and it was somewhat highlighted, Sir, in a conversation I once had with a very intelligent Malayan whom I sought to enrol in the Labour Front. He said to me, "The Labour Front is too pro-Chinese. With multi-lingualism, you are going to hand us over to the Chinese. They will swamp us." Sir, we must face these things in the open. It is no use hiding them. I tried to explain that as we saw things

Column: 1498

we did not believe in favouritism for any race. We were for justice and we were for political justice, which is democracy; that if one has faith and believes in democracy, then one must accept the rule of the majority. Yes, Sir, one must accept the rule of the majority. The Chinese are 76 per cent of our population. Let us not avoid the issue. I am not sugaring any pill. We will face it squarely, Sir. This is a serious debate. As I see things, it is right and it is proper that the Chinese people should have a preponderant voice in the government of this country. But, Sir, I tried to explain - and I think it is important that we should here, in seeking to put the issues frankly before the House, also seek to allay the very genuine fears of a very honest group in our population.

    Democracy, though it means the rule of the majority, also means absolute respect for the rights of the minority. It means justice. Justice, Sir, does not mean that the majority can steamroller through. They have got to use their powers in harmony with the concept of natural justice and with respect for minority interests. My friend said - I hope the Chinese here would forgive me, but I think we ought to speak bluntly - "What do the Chinese know about democracy?" Sir, I can only speak as one man from my experience. I have lived with them, though not very closely, and I have gone to school with them. I have worked with them. I have been a clerk with them, and I believe that the Chinese people in Singapore - those I know, Sir - are one of the most adaptable people and in Singapore one of the most peaceable and reasonable. I am - and this is genuine, Sir - full of admiration for their capacity to appreciate the value of a new concept and to make the kernel of that new concept, the valuable aspect of it, their own. I believe, Sir, that given the opportunity the Chinese people will be equal not only to understanding the virtues of democracy, which I believe in wholeheartedly, but to making adoptions of parliamentary democracy their own and adding to that doctrine in its practice in this Colony their own magnificent vitality. Sir, I was asked by this man how I could expect that when the Chinese

Column: 1499

schools in Singapore give the same education as the schools in Amoy, and the schools in Amoy have produced Communists. I do not know about the schools in Amoy, Sir, and I would like to know a lot more about the schools in Singapore; but I do say this - that even from Amoy there have been refugees, refugees from the tyranny of Communism, into the quite squalid conditions of the refugees in Hongkong. I do know that here they have the opportunities to understand democracy. I hope they will have the opportunity to participate in it, and I believe they will be a new ally and a refreshing new strength to this process.

    Sir, I asked him what alternative he had, and he said, "Why cannot we leave it as it is - the English language?" These are arguments other Members must have heard, and I think it is well we should face them. I pointed out that if multi-lingualism hands us over to the Chinese, then English hands the people over to the very small English-speaking minority. He said, "Oh, we will be just to the Chinese." My reply was, "Why should we think the Chinese would not be just to the minority races?" Why should we imagine that under the process of democracy, which means majority rule, anybody would be submerged? Sir, in this very House we see examples of minorities having their full say without being submerged. We have seen in a solemn moment the expression of our deepest feelings, a single-Member Party - Mr Sutherland - standing up and saying that, on behalf of the English expatriate community, he deplored our desire for immediate self-government, and he voted against it and is working against it. Are they being submerged, even in the minor processes of democracy that we have, much though we may deplore the fact that those who find their prosperity from the people of the country should work against the deepest urges of those very people? Sir, we must have faith in the basic decency of all human beings. I ask the Asian minority races of Singapore not to give way to any emotional feelings of apprehension, to have faith in the value and in the triumph of parliamentary democracy. I would like to say in this connection that I am particularly

Column: 1500

proud, Sir - if you catch his eye - that my loyal friend and colleague the Hon. the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing will be supporting this motion wholeheartedly and seconding it.

    Now, Sir, on the second part of my motion. I ask for the appointment of a Committee. You see, Sir, many issues have to be clarified. There is the question of the system of translation - it is my hope that it will be a simultaneous translation through electronic or other devices. There is the question of additional and highly skilled staff; the question of the language of the official records; the question of amendments to our Standing Orders. Sir, there is no desire at all for any delay - I can assure you - because I will say this: that the draft instrument for amendment of the Singapore Colony Order in Council, Sir, has, I am reliably informed, been forwarded to the Regency Council and I anticipate that section 55 will be no more very shortly, and in fact even perhaps before the Committee has had time to report. It is essential that this House, when it proceeds to enforce it, should have it with the maximum possible efficiency.

    I am quite sure that though hon. Members here speak English, nevertheless to some of them English comes a little awkward - quite naturally - and they would prefer to speak one of the languages which I have indicated in my motion. I think they should have that opportunity. I hope they all should have that opportunity. I trust that nobody would seek to make use of this motion for purposes of public propaganda or purposes of gaining votes, because these additional languages do add in a small measure to the inconvenience of the Assembly, and I am quite sure that all Members will co-operate in seeking the comfort and convenience of the Assembly. But, nevertheless, we ourselves have experience that some of our hon. Members do find difficulty in expressing themselves in English and would be much happier, not for purposes of propaganda but sincerely in order to express themselves better, to use their own language.

    Sir, I therefore formally move the motion that stands in my name,

    That this Assembly is of the opinion that for the purposes of oral debate the languages of the Assembly should be English, Malay, Mandarin and Tamil; and that a Select Committee be appointed to examine, report upon and make recommendations in respect of matters necessary to enable effect to be given to the proposal.

    The Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing (Inche Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to second the motion now before this House.

    Yesterday, Sir, when the Chief Minister started his speech, he said he was not speaking as the Chief Minister of the Government of Singapore but as the Member for the Cairnhill Division. Today, Sir, I rise in the footsteps of my Chief Minister. I say I speak not as a Minister of the Government of Singapore, but as a representative of a group of people of this island who could be termed the minorities.

    Sir, this motion has the unqualified support of my people and also of the Party to which I belong. Looking towards the immediate future while this island is about to enter the doors of self-government and independence, one cannot but concede that there is a necessity, if not for the sake of national pride, at least for practical reasons, that the people of Singapore should be given an opportunity of voicing themselves in this Assembly in the language best suited to them. For over a hundred years, the affairs of public bodies, like this Assembly, have been conducted in the English language. It may well be for some to say that English is the universal language of the world, but to me, Sir, English is not the universal language of the people of Singapore. We all believe, quite rightly, too, that apart from other qualifications, representatives of the people should have a certain amount of education, but it is one of the peculiarities of this country that there are still some who accept the view that a person can only be educated if he is educated in the English language. Sir, there are thousands of people in Singapore-Chinese, Indians and Malays

Column: 1502

- who may not know the English language at all but who do not lack the ability nor the education to become leaders of the community. I do not see, Sir, why these people should be barred from sitting as Members of this Assembly. Sir, I support the motion.

    Question proposed.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy (Telok Ayer): Mr Speaker, Sir, I take pleasure in supporting the motion before the House. I wish the Chief Minister would not have taken credit for this motion or for many Bills which have been passed in this Assembly. I would like to deal with it first, Sir, because it has been stated by the Chief Minister.

    Sir, multi-lingualism was debated on this very Floor by the previous Legislative Council on the 28th of January, 1955. The motion was by a very intelligent local-born Indian, Mr C. R. Dasaratha Raj, and claiming a division, the voting for was:

    Sir, this is nothing new. It is the duty of any government to lake up the threads of the past in the interests of the people.

    Sir, Malayanisation - this motion was moved by me on the 18th of November, 1952. Those who wish to see the report can have a look at it. This motion was accepted by the Government as a whole and an ad hoc committee was appointed under the chairmanship of Sir Han Hoe Lim. This has been further pursued by this Assembly.

    Sir, Labour Code - this was a piece of legislation which was prepared by the previous Legislative Council. It was left over in the hands of the caretaker Government to bring forward in this new Assembly.

    Sir, freezing of land values and the Master Plan - a lot of time and labour was devoted to these two subjects by the

Column: 1503

previous Government. They were also left over in the hands of the caretaker Government. The matter was taken up in1953, and my friend the Member for Seletar (Mr M. P. D. Nair) on a motion on 14th December, 1954, raised the question of land acquisition for a Second Reading.

    Sir, take the Employers and Employees Bill. This was brought into this Assembly by the Progressive Party, but what we have is the policy label of the Labour Government.

    The Chief Minister: That is a Government Bill.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: Given by the Progressive Party.

    The Chief Minister: That is a Government Bill.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: May I have the attention of the House, Sir, undisturbed?

    Mr Speaker: Continue, Mr R. Jumabhoy.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: I have enough of disturbance, Sir.

    Mr Speaker: Please continue.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: Sir, I think I have no doubt that I must give credit to the Labour Coalition Government for bringing in the Public Security Bill. Sir, coming to the motion now before the House, as I supported before, so am I supporting it now in the interests of the people. What should be the languages for this Assembly? We have got English. We, have got Malay which is spoken, not written, by almost all people. Then we have got Chinese. It is for the Chinese to decide what language is to be used. As far as the Indians are concerned, the majority of the Indians in this country are Tamil-speaking - over 70 per cent. The Indian community as a whole will gladly support the Tamil language.

    Then, Sir, the Chief Minister unfortunately brought in the subject of racial disharmony if this was to take place - it was only a possibility, he said - and

Column: 1504

he brought in Bombay also. Sir, I have just come back from Bombay. The disturbances there are not at all concerned with language. It is to have Bombay within its own state. It is just like Singapore should go to Johore or to Penang - something like that - but it has nothing to do with language.

    Sir, multi-lingualism has been practised successfully in Switzerland, and there is no cause for disharmony in this country as far as the Indians are concerned. As I have said, Sir, the majority of Indians here are Tamils and I must give them credit for the fact that in the partition days not a single case of murder took place in that area. So you will realise that the Indians have lived here peacefully for centuries, even before the British came in, with the other communities and they will preserve the same state of harmony and peace.

    Sir, what is happening in India today? Even though about ten per cent of the population, or even less, is English-speaking, and even though India has gained independence nearly nine years now, the English language is still maintained, although they have decided that in 15 or 20 years' time, by a slow process, they can replace it with the official language, Hindi. On the other hand, the provincial languages are allowed in all the respective provinces, that is, Hindi, English and any other provincial language. I think, when the Committee comes to consider the question of multi-lingualism, they will take a leaf out of India's book for study and guidance.

    Sir, what happens if and when a united Malaya comes? Well, that is for the future; what will be its language? Many may argue that that might wait. I do not think why it should wait. Things will take their own course. Sir, as in the previous Legislative Council, I wholeheartedly support this motion.

    Mr John Ede (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to support the motion on behalf of the Liberal-Socialist Party. One of the objects in the Party's policy is the introduction of multi-lingualism in the Assembly, and in laying down that

Column: 1505

policy we had in mind precisely what this motion envisages, namely, that for the purposes of oral debate, the languages of the Assembly should be English, Malay, Mandarin and Tamil, it being implied that for the time being at least the written word should continue to be in English alone.

    I would also add that I do not subscribe to this view simply as a loyal Party man, but I have come to the personal belief that this is not a retrograde step, as some of us would like to believe, but a forward move in the best ultimate interests of the country. As the only elected European in this Assembly, I have to ask myself whether it is right to maintain, as the only vehicle of speech in the country's Legislature, a language which, while it can claim in some sense to be as indigenous as any other (if we take 1819 as the starting point in Singapore's history), is not the only living language on this island.

    And to this thought there must be added another one. Secondary school education in Government English schools was very badly neglected until the old Progressive Party began pressing for it in recent years, and thousands of citizens have not had adequate opportunities of learning the language in which they have at present to be proficient should they wish to play their part in public affairs.

    A third point then arises. In a country which is close to self-government, is it possible to resist the argument that it must have the right to choose the language or languages in which its elected representatives shall conduct the business of the Legislature? Common sense, quite apart from sentiment, supplies the answer.

    I now come to two objections which have been voiced on this subject. The first one is that it would be better to experiment with multi-lingualism, first at the local government level rather than in the Assembly. My own view is that there will be more practical difficulties encountered at the City Council level than in this House. Local government is concerned with more detailed matters, and even personal problems, than the

Column: 1506

Assembly; such things as unauthorised structures and frontages, hawkers and sewage connections and so on. Most of the discussions on these matters take place in Committees and not in open forum, and I can foresee the danger of a great slowing down in the work of the City Council if multi-lingualism is introduced without its difficulties having first been ironed out. I have had some experience of these difficulties as a Municipal Commissioner in an Indian city where the languages were English, Hindi and Urdu. We shall find difficulties in this House - I have no doubt. We shall have, to some extent, to learn new techniques of procedure, but I believe the snags, whatever they may be, can best be smoothed out here first under the able guidance of Mr Speaker.

    The second objection is that the introduction of multi-lingualism will tend to encourage racial consciousness and racial antagonisms. I believe that, given the abundance of goodwill which exists in Singapore and given expert interpreters of the highest standard, the very opposite may well prove to be the truth. I believe that, through spontaneous translation, we shall be drawn closer to the thoughts and the outlook of those from whom we are at the moment shut off from communication. Lack of understanding arises from the barriers of language, from asking people to speak in a language in which they cannot think freely, and from maintaining the exclusiveness which one language imposes.

    We support this motion and we ask for its early implementation, for it is the first step on the road to finding out for ourselves and of our own free choice the most suitable language or languages to be the lingua franca of the future, a problem over which we must hasten, but hasten slowly.

    As I stated in this House in the Budget session, all the four main languages and cultures are needed to make up that composite thing that can be called Malayan nationalism, and they must be regarded as complementary to each other and not as existing separately in water-tight compartments. Where we have gone wrong is in the propaganda

Column: 1507

so prevalent today - and I hope I give no offence, as I mean none - which postulates that Chinese culture and the Chinese system of education are the exclusive property of the Chinese and must not be tampered with; that Malay culture and Malay history are being deliberately obliterated; and that the English language and European customs, predominant for many years because of British rule, seek obstinately to maintain their predominance amid a growing Asian consciousness. The antagonisms which are being engendered by this propaganda are all the more intense because there is no single obvious lingua franca for an independent Singapore of the near future.

    Malay has claims, because it is the oldest living language of Malaya, is shared by the millions of our neighbours in Indonesia, and is spoken to some extent by the large majority of peoples living in Malaya of whatever race. Its handicap is that it has no common usage outside South-East Asia and it is not well enough equipped for the expression of modern scientific thought.

    Chinese, too, has claims, because it is spoken by roughly half the population of Singapore and Malaya, because of its long history, longer even than Malay or English, and its great cultural heritage. Its handicap is that it is not an indigenous language, is used almost exclusively by the Chinese people alone, and is not strongly equipped to cope with modern science, although I believe that this difficulty is to some extent being overcome.

    English has claims, because it is the language of international gatherings and modern scientific thought. Its importance is inescapable because of its contacts for us with the rest of the world. Its handicap, however, is that it bears the stigma, rightly or wrongly, of being the language of the now nearly defunct colonial era and because its culture is foreign and imposed from without. English is the present lingua franca. Whether it will remain so is not for me to say, but so long as English is the main language of international trade and commerce, and so long as Singapore is

Column: 1508

to retain its proud position as a leading international port - as indeed it must - it seems to me imperative that English remains the language of communication with the outside world.

    Lastly, Tamil, if I may be pardoned for saying so, has the least claim of the four main languages, simply because it happens to be spoken by the smallest number of people.

    And so let us recognise that the introduction of multi-lingualism in this House, however desirable today, is a makeshift and not the most important thing we have to do. The Liberal-Socialist Party considers that what we must do, and do with all possible speed, is to make our people multi-lingual by giving facilities to learn at least three languages, so that they can converse with one another and understand one another without interpreters and earphones.

    Let us indeed keep the proposed multi-lingual scheme down to the absolute minimum cost, so that most of our funds can go into welding together a composite nation through multi-lingual education. So when the day comes to choose a lingua franca, perhaps I may be pardoned for hoping that it may be English, partly out of sentiment no doubt, but mainly because I believe the English language is the greatest single living unifying force in the world today. But whether or no that will be the choice, the decision must come from the people themselves and not be imposed from without.

    Mr G. A. P. Sutherland (Nominated): Mr Speaker, Sir, I had thought no Member of any political Party would offer outright opposition to the motion before the House, because it would be political suicide to do so - almost as bad as saying, "I like the British!"

    The Chief Minister: I, too, like the British.

    Mr Sutherland: I freely admit - I was quoting the Chief Minister, Sir, actually in his initial speech in this House - that, prima facie, it seems reasonable that

Column: 1509

locally-born people should not be debarred from being elected to this Assembly simply because they do not speak English; but the Chief Minister himself has admitted that his proposal is bristling with difficulties. If we examine the motion, what do we find? We find that "for the purposes of oral debate the languages of the Assembly should be English, Malay, Mandarin and Tamil." The records, notices, Bills, etc., as the Member for Tanglin (Mr John Ede) has just said, would doubtless continue to be in English, and I think the Chief Minister has also intimated that possibly for a period of years the records might continue in English. In that interim period we could have the somewhat anomalous situation of a Member being elected to this House and taking part in the oral debates but being unable to understand a single word of the papers passed to him.

    The Chief Minister said yesterday that non-English speaking Ministers could have one or two secretaries, but what about the ordinary Assemblyman? He might find it rather difficult to employ a secretary on his Assemblyman's pay - a secretary that could produce adequate translations of all the papers that come to him even late at night for the next day's sitting, unless he had a talented and erudite wife who might do it in her spare time.

    Now, admittedly there might be Members in this House who were merely not fluent in English and whose oratorical powers were greater in their own language - I think there may be some such in this House today but on the other hand, a Member might - in the interim period I am talking about - be entirely illiterate in English.

    Now, Sir, what of the choice of languages other than English? If we must have more than one language, then it seems to me that the Malay tongue has at least the right of precedent. But the statement made by the Member for Telok Ayer (Mr R. Jumabhoy) and the Member for Tanglin (Mr Ede) that Malay is spoken by the great majority of the people in Singapore is, in my opinion, quite wrong. I do not myself

Column: 1510

believe that very many people in Singapore can speak Malay at all. When I say that, I mean a Malay that can be used as a vehicle in this House. If I may just introduce a little personal note, Sir? I was coming to the last sitting of this Assembly two months ago and it was pouring with rain. My syce turned to me and said, "Banyak hujan, tuan." I thought now, let us see. I wanted to say, "Well, of course, there will be a lot of rain, it is the North-east monsoon just now. What do you expect?" So I said. "Oh, Betul, sekarang angin dan Utara-Timor." He turned to me with a blank face, so I thought that that was no good. I then came into the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association room here - I am sorry that the Member for Telok Ayer is not in his place - and I said to Mr R. Jumabhoy, "You speak Malay?" He replied, "Of course, I speak Malay." So I asked him, "Well, what is 'Northeast' in Malay?" He replied, "Oh, I do not speak that kind of Malay!" Then I approached the Hon. the Financial Secretary who I thought must, at least as a civil servant, speak reasonably good Malay, and I said to him, "Mr Hart, what is 'North-east' in Malay?", and he said, "Oh, I do not know."

    The Chief Minister rose -

    Mr Speaker: Point of order?

    The Chief Minister: Point of order, Sir. I do regret interrupting these delightful reminiscences, Sir, but may I draw the attention of the House to the rule that no aspect of the conduct of a Member outside the House should be referred to in the House, and although it does not really matter at the moment, it is a principle, Sir, and it should be adhered to?

    Mr Speaker: Will the Chief Minister indicate which Standing Order he is referring to?

    The Chief Minister: If it please you, Sir, it is 31 (9). I should like clarification, Sir, because I have myself constantly refrained from the references,

Column: 1511

thinking that we cannot say what a Member of the House did outside.

    Mr Speaker: That Standing Order reads:

    "The personal conduct of Members of the Assembly shall not be referred to except upon a substantive motion moved for that purpose."

    I hardly think that what a Member said or tried to say in respect of the Malay language is personal conduct! Mr Sutherland.

    The Chief Minister: Sir, I regret the interruption.

    Mr Sutherland: Thank you, Mr Speaker, Sir. Of course, I could have refrained from using the actual names of the people. It was just giving verisimilitude to my story. Anyway, if I may finish it - the hon. Gentleman whom I mentioned last came back to me, having contacted a Malay and he said, "The word is Tenggara." Sir, I went back that evening and looked up my dictionary and found that Tenggara is South-east!

    Sir, if we must have another language, then I should have thought the Malay tongue would have some right of precedence for obvious reasons; but I really see no valid reason for complicating matters by introducing Mandarin and Tamil. And why Mandarin? If this were an entirely Chinese Assembly, then I could see some reason for wishing to synthesize the various Chinese dialects, but the Assembly is multi-racial. Sir, I know many people - not Chinese, of course - think that acquiring a knowledge of Mandarin is quite a simple thing. They know that the written ideograph is universally understood and they imagine that, by a little modification of the tones and adjustment of a few hundred vocables, then anyone, for example, a Hokkien, can, with very little trouble, speak Mandarin. But it is not nearly as simple as that. Sir, it is true that Mandarin is more widely understood today than it was 20 years ago, but there are tens of thousands of Chinese in this island who do not understand a word of it. To tell the truth, I was quite astonished yesterday to hear the Chief Minister say that most Chinese in Singapore thought it would be their truly

Column: 1512

representative Chinese language. To my mind, that sounded like a statement of the Chinese Chamber of Commerce!

    Sir, if a mono-lingual Member or Minister can have a secretary or two secretaries, then I do not really see why we should not have one or two extra translators, and instead of having Mandarin we could have Chinese Members speaking in Fukienese or Cantonese or Hainanese or any of the other dialect; and in this motion, for the word "Mandarin" we simply substitute "Chinese". It seems to me, as it refers to oral debates why only have Mandarin? Most of them do not understand it.
